field_edited_text.value:
Immigrants at Locust Point, 1904







@
_ged
o9
eSe0es"
5 9e9e,9-"

- >

’.
- ®

Controversy over the neutrality issue, as
well as conflicting land claims in the west,
led to war with Great Britain in 1812 which
Baltimoreans supported enthusiastically.
The privateer “clippers” were unleashed
on British shipping with remarkable success.
Then, in September 1814, the city was faced
with defending itself against a British fleet
and army which was bent on destroying
what they called “that nest of pirates on
the Chesapeake.” In the event, the narrow
entrance to the harbor guarded by Fort
McHenry proved impregnable and Balti-
more achieved immortality through a
patriotic poem written by Francis Scott Key
describing the attack. That poem, later set
to music, is now our national anthem.








The war-stimulated economy virtually
collapsed with the declaration of peace
and Baltimore suffered a depression for
years. The remedy came from a radical
source of motive power—the steam engine.
The first steamboat in this area was built in
Baltimore in 1813 and appropriately named
the Chesapeake. In fact, the steamboat
caused a revolutionary change in the
economy of the Chesapeake Bay. In a
short time dozens of boats plied the bay
and its many rivers from Richmond to
Chestertown and points between, bringing
the tobacco of southern Maryland and
Virginia and the fish, oysters, and farm
produce of the tidewater to Baltimore.
From Baltimore went household goods,
fertilizers, and every sort of supplies.
Baltimore was now the commercial entry
port of the region, and because the bay
steamer was both shallow-draft and very
maneuverable, this commerce docked in
the heart of the city along Pratt and Light
Streets. o
